unit.title: Communication and You
unit.overview: In this unit, learners develop polite, effective communication skills in everyday Ghanaian contexts. They practise greetings and introductions, reading for meaning, and foundational grammar (nouns and pronouns). Activities are short and interactive to reduce fatigue, and include moral themes from Ghanaian/Christian perspectives.
competencies: Listen and respond appropriately in conversations with peers and adults.
Use nouns and pronouns accurately in simple and compound sentences.
Read short texts and identify main ideas and details.
Write a short paragraph to introduce oneself with correct punctuation and cohesion.
Demonstrate respectful language aligned with Ghanaian cultural norms and Christian moral values.
values_morals: Respect for elders and peers in speech.
Kindness: 'A gentle answer turns away wrath' (Proverbs 15:1).

lessons.title: Greetings and Introductions
objectives: Use polite greetings and forms of address for different audiences.
Introduce oneself clearly (name, school, hometown, interest).

vocabulary.definition: Polite and respectful in speech and behaviour.
A greeting used at the start of a conversation or letter.
Accepted rules for polite behaviour in society.

lessons.moral_link: Show respect through tone and word choice; greet elders first.

content_blocks.body: Ghanaians value respectful greetings. Use 'Good morning/afternoon/evening' and appropriate titles such as Sir, Madam, Auntie, or Uncle.
Smile, make eye contact, and speak clearly. Keep your introduction short: name, class, school, hometown.

quick_check.q: Which greeting shows the most respect to an elder?

speaking_task.prompt: Record a 20–30 second introduction. Include your name, class, school, and one interest.

lessons.title: Nouns and Pronouns in Conversation
objectives: Identify common, proper, and collective nouns in short texts.
Choose correct personal and possessive pronouns to avoid repetition.

vocabulary.definition: The noun a pronoun refers to.
How well ideas connect in writing or speech.

lessons.moral_link: Clarity shows respect for listeners—be clear and accurate.

content_blocks.body: Nouns name people, places, things, and ideas: Ama, Accra, market, honesty.
Pronouns replace nouns to avoid repetition: Ama forgot her book. She borrowed one.

drag_drop.prompt: Match each pronoun to its antecedent in the passage.

ai_task.prompt: Rewrite: 'Kofi met Kofi’s teacher at Kofi’s church.' Replace repeated nouns with correct pronouns.

lessons.title: Reading for Meaning: A Visit to Auntie Ama
objectives: Read a short narrative and identify main idea and supporting details.
Infer character feelings from actions and dialogue.

vocabulary.definition: Friendly and generous treatment of guests.
A movement that expresses an idea or feeling.

content_blocks.title: A Visit to Auntie Ama
content_blocks.body:
It was Saturday afternoon when Efua visited Auntie Ama in Kasoa. Before Efua could knock, Auntie Ama opened
the door with a warm smile. She offered water first, then asked about school. When Efua spoke, Auntie Ama
listened carefully, nodding and asking gentle questions. As Efua prepared to leave, Auntie Ama said,
'Remember, kind words build bridges.' Efua felt lighter walking home.

comprehension.q: What is the main idea of the passage?
options: Auntie Ama models kindness and good listening.

comprehension.q: Which detail best supports the main idea?
options: Auntie Ama offered water and listened carefully.

comprehension.q: The phrase 'kind words build bridges' suggests:
options: Words can connect people and solve problems.
You should never speak to strangers.

lessons.title: Grammar Workshop: Nouns, Pronouns, and Agreement
objectives: Ensure pronouns agree in number and person with antecedents.
Edit short texts for consistency and cohesion.

vocabulary.definition: Matching in number and person between words (e.g., noun–pronoun).
Keeping the same form or idea throughout a text.

lessons.moral_link: Be consistent and truthful in how you represent people.

content_blocks.body: Pronoun–antecedent agreement: 'The class finished its test.' (not 'their test').
Maintain point of view: avoid switching from 'I' to 'you' without reason.

error_hunt.text: The choir practised their songs. Ama is a prefect; they leads the prayer. Every student must bring their pencil.
error_hunt.solution_hint: Collective nouns like 'choir' often take singular agreement in Ghanaian English: 'its'.

options: Each pupil must submit their homework.
Each pupil must submit his or her homework.

mini_quiz.q: Select the sentence with correct agreement.

lessons.title: Writing Your Introduction
objectives: Write a cohesive 6–8 sentence paragraph to introduce yourself.
Use correct capitalisation, punctuation, and pronouns.

vocabulary.definition: Logical flow of ideas in a text.

lessons.moral_link: Be honest and humble in self‑presentation.

content_blocks.body: Model paragraph shows topic sentence, supporting details, and concluding sentence.

scaffold: Topic sentence: Who are you? (name, class, school)
Detail 1: Where are you from or what do you value?
Detail 3: A goal for the term.

quiz_mcq.q: Which is the most appropriate greeting to an elder in the morning?
Choose the sentence with correct pronoun use.
options: Efua met Efua’s teacher and Efua thanked Efua.
Efua met her teacher and she thanked her.
my name is yaw i attend Adabraka JHS
My name is Yaw; I attend Adabraka JHS.

writing_prompt.prompt: Write a cohesive paragraph (6–8 sentences) introducing yourself to your new English teacher. Include your name, class, one value you hold, one interest, and a goal for this term.

speaking_task.prompt: Deliver a 30‑second oral introduction using a polite register and clear pronunciation.
